content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays a cross-section of tissue, likely a colorectal resection specimen. I can identify a large, irregular, and highly cellular (dark purple/basophilic) mass that is characteristic of a primary tumor. Adjacent to this, there appears to be at least one, possibly two, structures with the ovoid shape and dense cellularity of lymph nodes. The overall architecture is disrupted, suggesting an invasive process.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The green box is placed on a large, well-circumscribed, basophilic structure that strongly resembles a lymph node that has been infiltrated and largely replaced by tumor. To determine the N stage (lymph node status), it is critical to examine any potential lymph nodes for metastatic deposits. This specific area is the most prominent and suspicious-looking lymph node; therefore, zooming in is essential to confirm the presence of carcinoma and assess the extent of nodal involvement (e.g., extracapsular extension). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-magnification view confirms the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The tissue is composed of complex, crowded, and branching glandular structures, with some areas showing a cribriform pattern. The neoplastic cells exhibit significant atypia, with elongated, hyperchromatic, and stratified nuclei. There is intraluminal necrotic debris (so-called 'dirty necrosis'), which is a characteristic feature of colorectal adenocarcinoma. An area of hemorrhage/necrosis is visible on the left. This field of view shows a lymph node almost completely effaced by metastatic carcinoma, confirming it as a positive lymph node.
